doc.title: Transport

passages.text: Global container volumes were up \(+2.4\%\) y/y in June, bringing 1H growth to \(4.0\%\) which likely benefitted from front loading ahead of tariffs. Port of LA volumes increased \(+8.5\%\) y/y in July, making it another record month for the port. However, cargo booking volumes have dropped by \(5 - 20\%\) in the past two weeks, as per Linerlytica. This is consistent with Port of LA bookings for the week of 24- 30 August showing a \(- 15\%\) w/w decline. Container liners have not cut capacity to meet the lower demand, meaning that a September rate hike appears unlikely. The global fleet has expanded by \(4.8\%\) with the order book to fleet ratio increasing to \(31\%\) as liners continue to order new ships. Spot rates have declined \(- 11\%\) in the past month \((- 42\%)\) YTD), with sharper corrections in the main Transpacific and Asia- Europe trade lanes of \(- 20\%\) . This brings rates to the US close to levels prior to the Red Sea disruption. Europe futures indicate a \(- 33\%\) decline by October. We continue to expect a big decline in rates due to an oversupplied market. Despite the declining spot rates, we note that container liner earnings in 3Q could be higher than 2Q given the timing of the rate decline and revenue recognition policies (CCFI index is tracking \(+8\%\) q/q in 3Q).

Global air freight rates were flat w/w, \(- 3\%\) y/y as per WorldACD data with weaker spot rates out of Asia- Pacific at \(- 8\%\) and Middle East & South Asia \(- 25\%\) . Overall global air freight volumes have declined sequentially in the past three weeks likely due to the summer holiday period and following the 1 August tariff deadline. The US de minimis exemption removal on rest of the world is effective from 29 August and could negatively impact air cargo demand. Postal service providers from a number of European countries including Germany have temporarily suspended service to the US due to this regulation change.

In its earnings call, ZIM said inventory levels remained stable until June this year despite strong container shipping industry volumes. Meanwhile Maersk's 2025 container market growth outlook has improved to \(+2\%\) to \(+4\%\) y/y (from \(- 1\%\) to \(+4\%\) ) on better- than- expected demand ex- North America. BAC US aggregated credit and debit card data shows US Retail (ex auto) card spending per household was up \(c3\%\) in the week ending 9 August. See the latest BofA on USA report for limitations, disclosures and methodology in connection with BAC card data. Euro area PMI improved to c51 in August while Europe consumer confidence declined.

\(>>\) Employed by a non- US affiliate of BofAS and is not registered/qualified as a research analyst under the FINRA rules. Refer to "Other Important Disclosures" for information on certain BofA Securities entities that take responsibility for the information herein in particular jurisdictions. BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Refer to important disclosures on page 17 to 18.
Equity Global Transport
Exhibit 1: SCFI Index based on Settled Rates (SCFIS), SCFI and EC futures
Source: Shanghai Shipping Exchange, Bloomberg BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
See pages 14- 15 for definitions of abbreviations used in the report.
Exhibit 2: Weekly import volumes at the Port of LA Port of LA import volume bookings declined c15% w/w in the week of 24- 30 August
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 3: Far East-Europe volumes (TEU) and growth (\%) Asia to Europe volumes were up c1% y-y in June 2025
TEU: Twenty-foot equivalent unit. Source:Alphaliner
Exhibit 4: Far East-US volumes (TEU) and growth (\%) Transpacific volumes were up c10% y-y in June 2025
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 5: Global container shipping volumes (\%) Global container volumes were up c2% y-y June 2025
Exhibit 6: Container shipping volumes at Port of Los Angeles (\%) Container volumes at Port of Los Angeles were up 9% y-y in July 2025
Source:Port of Los Angeles
Exhibit 7: Container shipping freight rates, indexed to January 2019 SCFI decreased by c11% month-on-month in August 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, Drewry, Bloomberg
Exhibit 8: SCFI indexes by trade lane
Exhibit 9: CCFI and SCFI Index SCFI index is down 42% since end-December
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics
Exhibit 10: SCFI Index based on Settled Rates (SCFIS), SCFI and EC futures The futures broadly imply a -33% decrease in Europe rates between now and end-October
Source: Shanghai Shipping Exchange, Bloomberg
Exhibit 11:CCFI quarterly average (2022-25) CCFI is 8% higher QoQ in 3Q25
Exhibit 12:SCFI quarterly average (2022-25) SCFI is 4% lower QoQ in 3Q25
SCFI is \(4\%\) lower QoQ in 3Q25
Short-term charter rates have been increasing m-m...
... and medium-term rates are broadly flat
Bunker fuel prices have been declining m-m...
...while high and low sulphur spreads are widening
Exhibit 17: Containership speed (daily average speed knots) Average speed declined marginally m-m in August...
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 18: Containership speed (daily average speed knots) ...and still below pre- Covid levels
Exhibit 19: Suez Canal - containership transits (TEU, 7dma) Container volumes have dropped significantly since mid- December 2023
Exhibit 20: Suez Canal - total number of transits (7dma) Container vessels saw a bigger impact from the disruptions
Exhibit 21: Global deployment by cellular TEU capacity (TEUM) Asia to Europe capacity increases by c8% YoY
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 22: Global deployment by TEU capacity in August 2025 (% of total) Asia-Europe and Asia- N. America dominate global trade lanes
Exhibit 23: Idled TEU (and % of global fleet) Idling (excluding capacity at shipyards) at c0.5% of global fleet
Exhibit 24: Idled TEU breakdown by vessel size (number) Inactivity increased slightly across size segments
Exhibit 25: Global orderbook to fleet (%) Global orderbook to fleet ratio was 31% in August
Exhibit 26: Deliveries per year (TEUm) and % of fleet Fleet deliveries to add \(>6\%\) to the fleet in 2025E
Exhibit 27: TEUs and units deleted during the year Deletions in 2025 are below 2024 levels...
Exhibit 28: Average TEUs and age of scrapped vessels ...with the average age of scrapped vessels slightly higher

Exhibit 29: Cellular fleet age breakdown
Average age of cellular fleet is 13.68 years
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Exhibit 30: Cellular fleet age breakdown (%)
The 20-24 years age profile represents c9% of the fleet
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 31: WorldACD air cargo chargeable weight (%YoY\*) for origin regions for the week of 11- 17 August  Europe volumes flat y- y while Asia Pacific were +9%
Source: WorldACD Note: \* y- y compares the last 2 weeks with the same 2 weeks last year
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 33: Baltic Exchange Air Freight Index  Global air freight rates were down - c2% w- w as of 25 August 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, TAC Index
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 32: WorldACD air cargo chargeable weight (%YoY\*)  Total worldwide tonnages were up +4% y- y in August (average weekly data)
Source: WorldACD Note: \* YoY compares the last 2 weeks with the same 2 weeks last year
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 34: WorldACD air cargo weekly rate (%YoY)  Average global rates were down 2% y- y in the week ending 17 August 2025 at \$2.43/kilo
Exhibit 35: WorldACD air cargo weekly rate (%YoY\*) for Origin Regions Africa and Europe saw an increase of \(+7\% /4\%\) in rates y-y in the week ending 17 August 2025
Source: WorldACD Note: \* YoY compares the last 2 weeks with the same 2 weeks last year BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 36: US ISM Manufacturing US PMI declined to c48 in July 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, Institute for Supply Management (ISM)
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 37: Eurozone Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) Euro area PMI improved to c51 in August 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, IHS Markit

Source: BAC internal data.

Source: BAC internal data.

Source: BAC internal data.
Exhibit 41: US furniture spending based on BAC aggregated daily card data (% YoY) US furniture spending was up \(C4\%\) YoY in the week ending 9 August
Source: BAC internal data.
Exhibit 42: US total manufacturing and trade inventories (Sbn) US manufacturing & trade inventories were up \(2\%\) YoY in June 2025
Source:US Census Bureau
Exhibit 43: US total manufacturing and trade inventory to sales ratio US total inventory to sales ratio decreased to 1.38 in June 2025
Source:US Census Bureau
Exhibit 44: US retail (ex-auto) inventories (Sbn) US retail inventories were up \(4\%\) YoY in June 2025
Source:US Census Bureau
Exhibit 45: US retail (ex-auto) manufacturing and trade inventory to sales ratio US retail inventory to sales decreased to 1.13 in June 2025
Source:US Census Bureau
Exhibit 46: US retail inventories by product category (Sbn) Most retail product inventory levels were above 2024 in June...
Source:US Census Bureau
Exhibit 47: US retail inventory to sales ratio by product category ...while most inventory to sales ratios were below 2024 in June
Source:US Census Bureau
Exhibit 48: US ISM Manufacturing Customers' inventories Index Customer Inventory Index decreased to c46 in July 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics Note: A reading of 50 means breakeven levels
Exhibit 49: US de-stocking cycle (ISM Manufacturing PMI new orders / inventories) New orders picked up while business inventories declined in July
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics
Exhibit 50: US ISM new orders vs global container shipping volumes CTS volume growth is above the new order growth reported by ISM Manufacturing PMI
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, Bloomberg
Exhibit 51: Consumer confidence indicators (Eurozone & UK, monthly) UK consumer confidence improved while Eurozone declined in August 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics
Exhibit 52: US consumer confidence indicator US consumer confidence improved in July 2025
Source: LSEG Data & Analytics, The Conference Board
MT: medium term USWC: US West Coast USEC: US East Coast TP: Transpacific ST: short term SCFI: Shanghai Containerized Freight Index ME: Middle East
FTK: Freight Tonne KilometreTEU: twenty-foot equivalent unitSCFI: Shanghai Containerized Freight IndexEC: EC futuresCCFI: China Containerized Freight IndexAFTK: Available Freight Tonne Kilometers
